front.title: IETF Trust Changes to Accommodate IASA Restructuring

abstract.t: The arrangements relating to administrative support for the IETF are underoing change within the IASA2 working group. The planned changes include replacing the current IETF Administrative Oversight Committee (IAOC) with a board for a newly created organisation with clearly defined interfaces towards the Internet Society and elsewhere. However, changes to IAOC will have an impact in the IETF Trust as well. This document describes the dependencies between the Trust and the IASA, and suggests path(s) forward that allow the IETF Trust to become independent of the IAOC changes, and continue its service to the IETF and others largely unchanged.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The arrangements relating to administrative support for the IETF (referred to as the "IETF Administrative Support Activity" (IASA) ) were created more than ten years ago, when the IETF initially took charge of its own administration. The arrangements have served the IETF reasonably well, but there's been considerable change in the necessary tasks, in the world around us, and our own expectations since the creation of the IASA. As a result, the IASA2 working group is proceeding to redefine the structure for IETF's administrative support.

As of the redefinition, the working group is planning to remove the IETF Administrative Oversight Committee (IAOC) and replace it with a board that oversees a new, formal organisation whose boundaries towards Internet Society (ISOC) and elsewhere are clearly defined.
However, the IAOC's is interwtined with another IETF organisation, the IETF Trust (), and as a result, changes to IAOC will also impact the IETF Trust.

The purpose of this document is to describe those impacts, and suggest path(s) forward that allow the IETF Trust's role to be defined independently of IAOC, and continue its important service to the IETF and other communities otherwise unchanged.

The rest of this document is organised as follows. describes what the IETF Trust is and how the current organisation is arranged. points out the depencies between IETF Trust and the rest of IASA, and how those dependencies require action in the context of IASA 2.0 project. discusses the general approach to these changes, i.e., minimal changes and keeping the IETF Trust as its own standalone entity. describes the specific changes that are needed, along with potential alternatives where they exist. Finally, discusses what needs to be done before these, final changes take effect.

section.title: Background
section.t: The purpose of the IETF Trust is to acquire, hold, maintain, and license certain existing and future intellectual property and other property used in connection with the administration of the IETF .

In practical terms, when IETF contributors submit materials such as those intended for publication as an RFC, they grant the IETF Trust gets some rights . The IETF Trust also manages trademarks and domains such as "IETF" and ietf.org. The IETF Trust is also serving the broader Internet community by holding domains and trademark associated with IANA .

The IETF Trust is a legal entity, registered in District of Columbia . It has a budget and is currently entirely funded by Internet Society. The 2018 expenses are expected to be 65,000 USD, or about 1% of overall IETF expenses . The main expenses relate to legal assistance and domain name and trademark registrations throughout the world.

Currently, the members of the IAOC are also serving as trustees of the IETF Trust. The founding documents specify persons eligible to become trustees as having to be then-current members of the IAOC . The documents also specify that if for any reason there are fewer than three individuals serving as trustees, then the IESG, or the IESG's successor as the leadership of the IETF, shall appoint one or more individuals to serve in a temporary capacity as Trustee(s) until eligible persons can be found.

In the current system there are eight IAOC members. They are named by the IETF Nominations Committee or NomCom (two members), IESG (one member), IAB (one member), Internet Society Board of Trustees (one member), along with three ex-officio members via their roles as IETF Chair, Internet Society CEO, or IAB Chair.

section.title: Dependencies
section.t:
The following dependencies exist:
The IETF Trust depends on having IAOC members as Trustees. A new arrangement for this needs to be found.
The IETF Trust continues to need a budget to manage its assets. As funding arrangements are changed in the rest of the system, it becomes necessary to specify how the IETF Trust is funded going forward, and if there's any change to the current arrangement.
The IETF Trust needs to allow organisations to use the trademarks and other assets its owns. As a new legal entity is created for IETF administration, it becomes necessary to authorize this new entity to use the assets that it needs.

section.title: General Approach
section.t: There are two basic approaches to resolving the dependencies. One could imagine merging all IETF Trust functions in the new IASA structure and under the planned new legal entity. This memo advocates a second approach where the IETF Trust is kept independent, but its dependencies on, for instance, IAOC members are resolved through other means.

The rationale for advocating the second approach is in part to avoid causing too much change for the IETF Trust at a time when the IETF administrative structure is ongoing major change. And, perhaps more importantly, the IETF Trust and other administrative IETF process are quite different. While very important, the IETF Trust is a very low activity entity where changes, if any, are minimal and gradual. There are no pressing issues, and the organisation serves the broader Internet community than perhaps the day-to-day and more IETF meetings-focused other parts of IASA.

section.title: Specific Changes to IETF Trust
section.t:
The memo suggests that funding for IETF Trust be centralized to come from the new IETF administrative support entity. One of the goals of the new entity is to be better in charge of all costs and income associated with the IETF, and putting the IETF Trust costs in the same place seems practical and reasonable.
An alternative model would be to continue to use funding directly from ISOC.

This memo also suggestes that the new IETF administrative entity be given rights to use the IETF domain names and trademarks, which seems reasonable given that the administrative entity is the one that administers the IETF web site anyway.

Finally, if we want to keep the IETF Trust separate as discussed in , there needs to be a new way to name trustees. At the time the trustees served both the IETF Trust and the IAOC, many of the requirements for naming a particular group of people were driven by the IAOC's requirements. For the IETF Trust in the new model, some of those arrangements can be rethought, both in terms of the number and source of the trustees, as well as the desired qualifications and length of terms.

Several options are possible, of course. A newly designed naming process could be devised. This memo argues for relatively limited change, however, largely on the basis of the IETF Trust arrangements generally working well, and on the relatively modest expected time commitments combined with the need for very careful management of the assets.

As a result, this memo suggests that a smaller group of five trustees is sufficient, with two named from by the Nomcom, one named by the IESG, one named by the Internet Society Board of Trustees, and the IETF Chair as an ex-officio member.

In addition, the terms for the Nomcom- and IESG-named trustees should be set to three years.
Note: It does not seem necessary for the IAB Chair or the Internet Society CEO to be members of the IETF Trust.
The normal IETF rules regarding recalls and other Nomcom-related processes continue to apply .
The next section discusses what document changes are needed to make these changes.

section.title: Required Documentation Changes
section.t: This document, if approved, will revise the current procedures defined in and .

In addition, the Trust Founding Documents need to be revised to specify how trustees can become eligible in the new arrangement. Such a revision belongs to the IETF Trust, with community review before making a change.

The rights of the new IETF administrative entity with regards to IETF Trust copyright, trademarks, and domain names need to be formally acknowledged. This also an action that belongs to the IETF Trust.

section.title: Transition
section.t: The new entity for IETF administration is being set up, and at some point, the IAOC will also be discontinued. Fortunately, there's no pressing need to change all the components at the same time. As discussed above (), the IESG holds the ability to continue to name trustees. Once the changes suggested in are in place, the IETF Trust will have management nominated in the usual manner, and the exceptional IESG process is no longer needed.

However, the following actions do need to take place when a new administrative entity is created:
There needs to be an agreement between the IETF and Internet Society that the IETF Trust shall be funded by either the Internet Society directly or through the new administrative entity. Perhaps this agreement can be a part of the operating agreement that is being drafted. And as discussed above, it seems logical that the IETF Trust funding will be arranged through the new administrative entity.
The new administrative entity needs to be given rights to use the IETF domain names and trademarks. This is normal IETF Trust business and can be handled in the usual manner.
